author: huntingisland
content: Regarding my question above, it appears that very few believe that Ethereum needs more than ~30% of ETH staked to provide excellent security for any applications that might run on Ethereum. Does that sound right?

author: huntingisland
content: I'm asking because based on whatever that percentage is, I think we should look at changing the ETH2 issuance curve at phase1 launch so we don't overpay beyond the number of stakers that are needed to provide robust security for Ethereum.

author: huntingisland
content: My idea is to leave the existing issuance curve alone to an appropriate level of "more than enough" security and then bend it hard once percent of ETH staked exceeds that.

author: djrtwo
content: yes, the rewards have been designed in such a way to target ~10M to 30M (in the upper range) ETH staked

author: huntingisland
content: ok, I am happy with the curve as is up to 30 million

author: djrtwo
content: I hear you on that, but at the same time the growth of issuance greatly diminishes in these top range numbers and the staking rewards are no longer attractive at all

author: huntingisland
content: yes. I would just like to bend it a little harder even though we are quite unlikely to see 50-60-70-90% of ETH staked.

author: djrtwo
content:
the issuance curve is definitely in the range to be a balance between incentivizing staking vs keeping issuance low

the fact that there are people concerned on both sides of the spectrum is at least a signal that we are in the equillibrium

author: huntingisland
content: I think the issuance curve looks good up to 30 million. I would like to see a lower total maximum past 30 million.

author: huntingisland
content: at 30 million ETH staked gross inflation is .94%

author: huntingisland
content: My suggestion is maximum gross inflation at 1%

author: djrtwo
content:
> yes. I would just like to bend it a little harder even though we are quite unlikely to see 50-60-70-90% of ETH staked.
for the sake of simplicity and not touching things I lean toward not messing with it.

this also makes a cliff where rationally validating falls off quickly rather than a more natural curve at which to find the sweet spot.

for validating at these very high numbers to be profitable, I would suppose that ETH would need to be worth orders of magnitude more than it is today. and in that case, I'm not certain we'll be debating about fractions of a percentage issuance. We'll instead have a ton of ETH locked and a super secure network üôÇ

author: huntingisland
content: What I am presenting is not a technical problem per se. It is a social problem. If we can present ETH2 as having gross inflation below 1% under any parameters, that is far more palatable than saying "ETH2 inflation will be below 1.72%"

author: djrtwo
content: more meme-able

author: huntingisland
content: yes, but also more palatable to people seeking protection from "money printer go brrrrrrrr"

author: huntingisland
content: of course Ethereum will not embrace a total ETH hard cap with zero issuance, so zealots will never be satisfied with any level of permanent issuance

author: huntingisland
content: however the moderate middle will like very much that Ethereum interoperates with the legacy financial system

author: huntingisland
content: while still providing protection from the extreme issuance that governments are conducting with their fiat currencies because of the Covid depression

author: huntingisland
content: From a technical standpoint, it sounds like the ETH2 researchers and developers are happy with 10-30% staked and no need for more than 30%

author: huntingisland
content: Are there staking attacks that make it inadvisable for setting an issuance hard cap?

author: huntingisland
content: ie: maximum percent issued per year

author: djrtwo
content:
I think the problem is that if we got near that point where the issuance switches to flat, an attacker can show up with only a moderate amount of additional capital to make it much less attractive to be validating for other rationale actors (thus being able to disproportionately discourage others from staking and playing into a class of economic attacks  called "discouragement attacks")

cc: <@!273808422753796097> -- Any other perverse incentives arise in switching from the current sqrt curve to the a flat curve in the middle?
